speaker: Monday, 23 October 2017 Country And Read Prayers. Petitions Committee Report The 45th Parliament. Hastings: Medical Centre This Petition Of Certain Citizens Of Australia Draws To The Attention Of The House To The Need To Provide Pharmaceutical Benefits After Hours In The Township Of Hastings And Environs At Premises Described As Unit 3, 9 Queens Street, Hastings, Victoria. The Granting Of Approval To Provide Pharmaceutical Benefits Would Enable Patients Attending The Hastings Family Medical Centre And The Hastings After Hours Medical Centre To Receive Their Prescribed Medicines Immediately At The Time Of Their Medical Consultation Thus Obviating The Need For Undue Delay In The Commencement Of Therapy That Would Be Occasioned By The Need To Return Next Day To Have Their Medicines Dispensed During Normal Business Hours. We Therefore Ask The House To: Request The Minister For Health To Exercise The Discretion Conveyed By Section 90a Of The National Health Act 1953 To Grant Mr Meyerson And Mr Morre Bryner Approval To Provide Pharmaceutical Benefits At The Designated Premises. From 1501 Citizens. Great Barrier Reef This Petition Of Young Students Of Australia Draws To The Attention Of The House: The Problem Of Extreme Coral Bleaching Of The Great Barrier Reef Due To Climate Change And The Water Of Australia Getting Warmer. Coral Bleaching Occurs When The Algae That Live In The Tissue Coral Polyps Get Rejected Or Expelled From The Coral. This Process Can Devastate The Reef Putting The Ecosystem At Risk. This Could Also Greatly Affect Tourism In The Great Barrier Reef And The Economy Will Also Be Affected. We Believe That The Great Barrier Reef Should Not Be Open To The Public, Because We Are Concerned That The Toxins Carried By Us Humans Destroys The Coral Making It White And Having A Bleached Effect. We Therefore Ask The House To: Make The Great Barrier Reef Less Accessible To The Public And More Accessible To Marine Biologists. This Action Will Give The Scientists An Opportunity To Research And Study The Reef To Teach Future Generations About The Reef Without Destroying This Wonder Of Nature. From 47 Citizens. Dental Health This Petition Of Young Student Citizens Of Australia Draw To The Attention Of The House: Teeth Are A Very Important Part Of Your Body, So Therefore Dental Care For All Australians Should Be Free And Covered By Medicare. Currently, Citizens With Private Health Insurance Have Access To The Dentist Immediately, But That Should Be The Same For All Australians With Or Without Private Health Insurance. Aboriginals' Dental Health Is 2 To 8 Times Worse Than Australians Due To The Prohibitive Cost Of Dental Care. People In Rural And Remote Areas Often Wait Around 2 To 3 Years For Free Government Treatment. The Best Medicine
theText: NA
title: Setup

speaker: The Speaker (Hon. Tony Smith) Took The Chair At 10:00, Made An Acknowledgement Of
title: Petitions

speaker: Mrs Wicks (Robertson) (10:01
theText: I present the 17th report of the Petitions Committee for
title: Petitions

speaker: Mrs Wicks (Robertson) (10:01
theText: I present the following petitions:for good dental health is a preventative oral hygiene regime including regular brushing and a healthy diet and regular check-ups and treatment at the dentist. Millions of people live with poor oral health due to the cost, because Medicare does not cover dental, this can make an impact on your health like diabetes and heart disease. We therefore ask the House to make free dental care to be included in Medicare. Regular check-ups are really important so why shouldn't the government pay to ensure that everyone can go to the dentist for free and have healthy dental care, because your teeth are a vital part of your body. from 51 citizens. Legal Drinking Age This petition of young stage 3 citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House: the health problems associated with young people drinking alcohol. We ask that the age restriction of drinking alcohol to be raised to 21 instead of the current 18 years of age. This is because most of us citizens have matured by this age and will know to drink sensibly. This will save many lives including the lives of the drinker. If you are under the age of 21, drinking alcohol can cause blackouts to your mind. It's not only this but 1/8 young Australians die because of underage drinking. If someone becomes addicted to alcohol at an early age, this could lead to long term drinking which can cause permanent brain damage. If you change the legal drinking age to 21 then this will have long term benefits for the health of all Australians. We therefore ask the House to: Change the age restriction for drinking to 21. This is a much more reasonable age as the brain has matured enough to know that drinking too much could cause death or harm to others. All of our lives depend on this answer. We ask you to raise the legal drinking age from 18 to 21 years of age. from 45 citizens. Climate Change This petition of concerned people of the electorate of Farrer, draws to the attention of the House the severe and urgent threat that climate change poses to the health, well-being and security of all people around the world, particularly our poorest and most vulnerable neighbours. We remind the House that Australia's greenhouse emissions are the highest per person among wealthy nations while our emissions reduction targets are among the weakest. We therefore ask the House to do all in its power to protect communities in Australia and our region from the harmful impacts of climate change such as more severe heat, extreme and unpredictable weather and rising seas by: committing to deeper and more urgent reductions of our greenhouse emissions; developing a plan to ensure Australia achieves zero net greenhouse emissions well before 2050, and supporting families and communities affected by the transition towards renewable energy and more sustainable land use; providing additional assistance to help our poorest neighbours adapt to the harmful impacts of climate change. from 110 citizens. Animal Welfare This petition of concerned citizens of Australian residing on the Gold Coast Queensland. It draws to the attention of the House the shocking and heart breaking torture and killing of millions of dogs in countries Australia has major trade relations with. In particular China, South Korea, and Indonesia. The majority of dogs are not vaccinated, many carry Rabies and there are hundreds of reported deaths a year from this disease. Dogs are hung, beaten, electrocuted, and treated cruelly by farmers and slaughters. Cats and dogs are blow-torched and boiled alive for medicinal elixirs. Video evidence is easily accessed on-line. The issue may appear as low priority however countries that allow brutality towards innocent animals are likely to have little or no respect for other humans. For Australia to totally ignore this gross inhumanity is incomprehensible. We therefore ask the House to: petition to end the cruel treatment of dogs and cats in China and South Korea. Help put an end to the dog and cat meat trade. More than 10,000,000 dogs are killed in China alone. from 376 citizens. Immigration Detention This petition of Grandmothers and other concerned citizens draws to the attention of the House the inhumane treatment of children and their families in closed immigration detention in Australia and Nauru. We therefore ask the House to end immigration detention of children in law and policy, to immediately release the children and their families and bring them to Australia while their protection claims are assessed, guaranteeing them all adequate housing, health care, education and legal representation. from 202 citizens. Northern Rivers Rail Trail This petition of the Northern Rivers Rail Trail and members of the community brings to the attention of the House the need for the Commonwealth Government to provide funding to match the $6.518 million already reserved by the NSW State Government. It is necessary that the Commonwealth Government invest a matching contribution to allow this project to succeed. The undersigned petitioners therefore ask the House to support the Northern Rivers Rail Trail and Tweed Shire Council by way of providing a matching contribution amount of $6.518 million towards this very worthwhile project from 1937 citizens. Petitions received. Responses to the House have been received as follows: Military Pensions Dear Mr VastaI refer to your letter of 13 February 2017 to the Minister for Finance, Senator the Hon Mathias Cormann, regarding Petition number EN0047. The petition has been referred to me for reply given the primary matter it raises is the splitting of military superannuation pensions for the purposes of property settlements made under the Family Law Act 1975 (Cth). My Department has consulted with the Treasury, the Department of Finance, and the Department of Defence in preparing this response. The petition makes two requests. First, the petition requests that a new exclusion for invalidity pensions paid under the Military Superannuation and Benefits Scheme (MSBS), and the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefit Scheme (DFRDB), be added to reaulation 12 of the Family Law (Superannuation) Regulations 2001. This regulation provides that certain payments in respect of a superannuation interest are not splittable payments for the purposes of section 90ME of the Family Law Act. Second, the petition requests that the formula in section 307.145 of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997 be amended so that it applies to a member in receipt of an MSBS or DFRDB invalidity pension. With respect to the first request, the policy underpinning the family law superannuation splitting regime is for there to be a just and equitable split between parties following a relationship breakdown. I am aware that various stakeholders have expressed concern about the way in which the family law superannuation splitting regime is being applied to military invalidity pensions. I appreciate these concerns. The views of interested parties are valuable in informing future family law policy. The Australian Government will continue to work with involved stakeholders to consider the broader policy issue that has been raised in the context of the petition, in particular, whether the family law superannuation splitting regime should apply to military invalidity pensions in circumstances where those pensions are reviewable. 2
title: Petitions

speaker: Mrs Wicks (Robertson) (10:01
theText: Ministerial responses to petitions previously presentedThe petition also requests that the formula in section 307-145 of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997 (ITAA 1997) be amended so that a medically retired member of the Defence force has an automatic entitlement to the formula whilst in receipt of an invalidity benefit. I am advised that section 307-145 is part of Sub-division 307-C of the ITAA 1997 which sets out the components of a superannuation benefit. The purpose of this sub-division is to ensure the appropriate taxation treatment of superannuation benefits by setting out the taxable and tax free components of a given superannuation benefit. Specifically, section 307-145 acts to increase the tax-free component where a disability superannuation interest is received as a lump sum. Separate arrangements apply where the disability superannuation benefit is received as an income stream. Section 307-145 already applies to benefit all members in receipt of a disability superannuation benefit. It therefore applies to benefit members of the MSBS and DFRDB that are receiving a disability superannuation interest. There is therefore no need to amend the provision to extend its application. The responsible adviser for this matter in my Office is Daniel Ward who can be contacted on (02) 6277 7300. Yours faithfully from the Attorney General, Mr Brandis Climate Change Dear Mr VastaI refer to your letter concerning the petition presented to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Petitions, regarding the Government's policies on climate change. The Australian Government is committed to playing its role in global efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Australia's ratification of the Paris Agreement reaffirms our commitment to effective international action on climate change. As part of this commitment, Australia has set a target to reduce emissions by 26 to 28 per cent below 2005 levels by 2030. The Government supports a technology neutral approach to our future electricity fuel supply. Coal and gas will continue to play an important role in the fuel mix, and will help to overcome some of the security and reliability issues that arise from intermittent generation types. Renewables will also play an important role in Australia's energy future. The Renewable Energy Target is helping to transform our electricity generation mix to cleaner and more diverse sources. The Government is also supporting investment in clean energy innovation through the Clean Energy Finance Corporation and the Australian Renewable Energy Agency. The Government welcomed the release of the Chief Scientist, Dr Alan Finkel's independent review into the future security of the National Electricity Market (NEM) on 9 June 2017. Dr Finkel's report provides the blueprint for ensuring Australia's energy system remains affordable, reliable and secure, while transitioning to low emission forms of generation. Business as usual is not an option if we are to meet the challenges of the once-in-a-century transformation taking place in Australia's energy system. Further information on Dr Finkel's review, including the final report can be found at: www.environment.gov.au/energyinational-electricity-market review. Thank you for the opportunity to respond to this petition. Yours sincerely from the Minister for the Environment and Energy, Mr Frydenberg Former Child Migrants Dear Mr Vasta Thank you for your letter of 22 May 2017 regarding petition EN0141 concerning the representation of Forgotten Australians, in particular by the Alliance for Forgotten Australians (AFA). Thank you for bringing this matter to my attention. The Commonwealth Government understands there are diverse experiences and views among Forgotten Australians and Former Child Migrants, and is committed to ensuring a range of voices and perspectives from within these groups continues to be heard. The Government delivered a National Apology to Forgotten Australians and Former Child Migrants at a special remembrance event in Canberra on 16 November 2009. As part of the National Apology, the Government agreed to promote and encourage greater recognition of Forgotten Australians and Former Child Migrants, also known as care leavers, by funding representative organisations including AFA, Care Leavers Australasia Network and the International Association of Former Child Migrants and their Families. These organisations are currently funded to 30 June 2020 as part of the national Find and Connect Support Services. In addition to consulting with these organisations regarding care leavers, my Department also convenes the Find and Connect Advisory Group. The Advisory Group provides a platform for national advice and communication between the Commonwealth Government, state and territory governments, representative groups, non-government organisations and service providers on the needs of Forgotten Australians and Former Child Migrants. In August 2016, my Department was advised of concerns with AFA, through a formal complaints process, and conducted an investigation into the conduct of AFA Board members and the policies, procedures and performance of the organisation. My Department's investigation found that AFA has been working intensively to strengthen its leadership, governance and management capacities to further build confidence in the organisation among internal and external stakeholders. This includes engaging an external independent consultant and the AFA Board endorsing new protocols to underpin these organisational enhancements. AFA has recently appointed an Executive Officer, which is a new position, to further strengthen its governance arrangements and to provide a more coordinated approach to effective communication with internal and external stakeholders, especially those who the organisation represents. My Department will continue to work closely with AFA to ensure its governance and strategic initiatives are implemented successfully and to foster an open and inclusive culture, both within MA and with external stakeholders. Based on the information at hand, I am satisfied that MA's commitment to organisational improvement enables the organisation to continue to be one of a number of relevant voices promoting and encouraging greater recognition of Forgotten Australians and Former Child Migrants. Thank you for raising this matter with me. Yours sincerely from the Minister for Social Services, Mr Porter National Broadband Network Dear Mr Vasta Thank you for your letter of 22 May 2017 regarding the petition (EN0166) proposing the use of fibre optic connections in the fixed line National Broadband Network (the network) footprint to enable sustained telephony services during power outages. The Australian Government is committed to ensuring that all Australians have reliable access to emergency assistance when needed. The effectiveness of telecommunications in emergencies is treated seriously, and the Telecommunications Act 1997 ensures that all telecommunications service providers meet certain standards as part of these responsibilities. However, it is important to note that no form of telecommunications technology can provide 100 per cent resilience during power outages or natural disasters. The copper lines used in the Public Switched Telephone Network (PSTN) provided a fortuitous benefit that allowed for the continued operation of analogue corded telephone services in power outages. However, if the outage affected nearby telecommunications pillars, local telephone exchanges, or the fixed lines from the exchange to a premises, even telephony services over the all-copper network were disrupted. In addition, irrespective of the network technology used, devices such as cordless telephones, modems and other powered equipment in households will not work in a power outage unless they are connected to an in-premises uninterruptible power supply. The provision of this household backup power is the consumer's responsibility. The network rollout involves several new technologies and, depending on the technology connected to a premises, there may be different battery backup options available. For this reason, customers are always encouraged to contact their retail broadband and telephony provider to discuss the full details and options available to them. Furthermore, it is strongly recommended that people do not rely solely on telecommunications services in emergencies. A range of information sources should be used in an emergency to stay aware of local conditions. These information sources may include radio (ideally battery-powered), television, and State or Territory emergency services websites if mobile data services are available in the event of a fixed-line outage. Finally, mobile phone use is now almost universal, and the vast majority of premises in the network fixed line footprint are in areas that have good access to mobile coverage. All mobile phones in Australia can make calls to Triple Zero, provided they are operational (e.g. have sufficient battery life) and in an area in which mobile coverage is provided by at least one mobile service provider. Special roaming capabilities of the vast majority of mobile phones mean that if a user is out of their own service provider's coverage area when calling Triple Zero, but still within coverage of another carrier's mobile network, their call will be re-routed automatically via the other carrier's network. This means that, even if a mobile phone has no SIM card inserted or call credit (whether pre or post-paid), a user should still be able to make a call for emergency assistance from most locations in Australia. Yours sincerely from the Minister for Communication and the Arts, Mr Fifield Paid Parental Leave Dear Mr Vasta Thank you for your letter of 20 June 2017 regarding petition number EN0172 about the Australian Government's Paid Parental Leave scheme. The petition calls for changes to the Paid Parental Leave scheme to allow men to apply for Parental Leave Pay as the sole carer of their child, regardless of the mother's circumstances. The provision of Parental Leave Pay under the Paid Parental Leave Scheme is primarily intended to help support mothers to take time out of the workforce to care for their newborn or recently adopted child. It also aims to enhance the health and development of the child and to allow time for the mother to recover from the child's birth. Based on these objectives, the scheme gives eligible mothers the initial entitlement to Parental Leave Pay but allows them to transfer the entitlement to eligible partners who take on the role of primary carer. The requirement in the scheme for a mother to have primary eligibility for Parental Leave Pay is based on the view that a mother needs time to recover from the birth and bond with her baby, and that the mother has a unique capacity to breastfeed her baby, with the health and other benefits this has for the mother and child. I note the view that equal access for men and women to Parental Leave Pay will allow each family to decide what is best for them. However, this approach would not meet two of the primary objectives of the scheme: to support mothers to take time off work after the birth of their child and to encourage women's continued workforce participation. Thank you for raising this matter with me. Yours sincerely from the Minister for Social Services, Mr Porter Food Labelling Dear Mrs Wicks Thank you for your letter of 8 August 2017 to the Minister for Health and Minister for Sport, the Hon Greg Hunt MP, regarding Petition number EN0176 which requests a change in food labelling laws to oblige food manufacturers to be specific about the spices used in their products to inform consumers with an allergy to certain spices. This matter has been referred to me as the Assistant Minister for Health with portfolio responsibility for this matter. I apologise for the delay in responding. Food Standards Australia New Zealand (FSANZ) is the statutory agency responsible for the development and maintenance of food standards and other food-related regulatory measures in Australia. All foods produced or imported into Australia are required to comply with the Australia New Zealand Food Standards Code (the Code). The Code is accessible through the FSANZ website at http://www.foodstandards.gov.au/Pages/default.aspx. Standard 1.2.3 Information requirements warning statements, advisory statements and declarations, of the Code requires declaration of major food allergens (peanut, lupin, tree nuts, milk, egg, sesame seeds, soybean, fish, crustacea and wheat) and food substances which can cause severe reactions through food intolerances (sulphites, and cereals containing gluten) whenever they are present in food. These allergens and substances must be declared on the label of packaged food. For unpackaged food the information must be declared on, or in connection with, the display of the food or declared to the purchaser on request. The foods listed in Standard 1.2.3 require mandatory labelling because they are recognised by medical experts as being frequently associated with severe adverse reactions, including anaphylaxis in sensitive individuals in Australia. The list in Standard 1.2.3 is generally consistent with major international requirements for mandatory declarations of foods or substances causing allergies or intolerances, based on factors such as the public health significance (for example, the extent of impact on the population generally). FSANZ has advised me that it is unaware of any clinical evidence that suggests that spices are of particular public health concern in Australia. 1 recognise for an individual affected by reactions to certain food(s) that this is of significant concern to them personally, even though it may not trigger regulatory intervention for the population more broadly. At present, the Government does not intend to review allergen labelling requirements. However, I understand FSANZ monitors emerging scientific information and international developments in the area of food allergens and food intolerances, with a view to determining whether any changes to the Code may be warranted in the future. For individuals with an allergy to certain spices, contacting the manufacturer of a food can be a method of obtaining information not provided on the label. The Code requires that a manufacturer's name and business address is provided on the label of a food, and many manufacturers also provide a free-call telephone number. Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention. Yours sincerely from the Assistant Minister for Health, Mr Gillespie Food Certification Dear Mrs Wicks Thank you for your letter of 8 August 2017 regarding a petition on halal certification (EN0190) presented in the House of Representatives on 19 June 2017. I am aware that a number of Australians are concerned about the practice of halal certification in Australia and would like to affirm that the government respects the religious needs of all community sectors, including those of the Islamic faith. Australia has a well-earned reputation as one of the most successful and cohesive multicultural societies in the world today. This success is based on respect for one another's human rights, the law and core values. Australia's approach to cultural diversity recognises that our multicultural character gives us a competitive edge in an increasingly globalised world. I have reviewed the petition and believe any legal or policy adjustments are best considered in the context of the government response to the Senate Economics References Committee's inquiry into third party certification of food, which was tabled on 2 August 2017. The government response can be found at www.aph.gov.au/Parliamentary_Business/ Committees/Senate/Economics/Food_Cert_Schemes/Additional_Documents. The government is acting constructively in response to the Senate Committee's recommendations. I note that when the Standing Committee on Petitions has considered this response it will be presented in the House and be posted on the Committee's website. Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention. I trust this information will be of assistance to you. Yours sincerely from the Minister for Agriculture and Water Resources, Mr Joyce Citizenship Dear Mrs WicksI refer to correspondence from Mr Ross Vasta MP of 20 June 2017 enclosing Petition EN0193, concerning the Australian Government's reforms to strengthen the requirements for Australian citizenship. The package of reforms announced by the Prime Minister on 20 April 2017 is the Government's response to the National Consultation on Citizenship, which indicated strong support for strengthening the requirements for Australian citizenship. The package of reforms includes: increasing the general residence requirement; introducing an English language test; strengthening the Australian values statement; strengthening the test for Australian citizenship; introducing a requirement for applicants to demonstrate their integration into the Australian community; and strengthening the pledge. All applications received on or after 20 April 2017 will be affected by the changes. The Australian Citizenship Legislation Amendment (Strengthening the Requirements for Australian Citizenship and Other Measures) Bill 2017 was introduced into the Parliament on 15 June 2017. The Bill is currently before the Senate. I note the concerns raised in the petition about the reforms, in particular the date the reforms will come into effect. The date of commencement was informed by experiences of previous Australian governments announcing reforms to programmes in the portfolio including the citizenship programme. The Department of Immigration and Border Protection is still accepting applications for Australian citizenship and does not anticipate that the process of reform will delay the processing of new applications lodged from the date of the Government's announcement. Indicative processing times are now published monthly on the Department's website. As of June 2017, 75 per cent of citizenship applications are processed within 11 months, from lodgement to conferral at a citizenship ceremony. Further information on processing times is available at: http://wvvw.bordergov.au/about/access¬accountability/service-standards/global-visa-citizenshipprocessing-times. Further information on Australian citizenship, including details on the reforms, can be found at: http://www.border.gov.au/Trav/Citi. Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention. Yours sincerely from the Minister for Immigration and Border Protection, Mr Dutton Citizenship Dear Mrs WicksI refer to correspondence from Mr Ross Vasta MP of 20 June 2017 enclosing Petition EN0194, concerning the Australian Government's reforms to strengthen the requirements for Australian citizenship. The package of reforms announced by the Prime Minister on 20 April 2017 is the Australian Government's response to the National Consultation on Citizenship, which indicated strong support for strengthening the requirements for Australian citizenship. The package of reforms includes: increasing the general residence requirement; introducing an English language test; strengthening the Australian values statement; strengthening the test for Australian citizenship; introducing a requirement for applicants to demonstrate their integration into the Australian community; and strengthening the pledge. I note concerns raised in the Petition about the increased general residence requirement. Applicants will need to be a permanent resident in Australia for a period of four years immediately prior to their application for citizenship, during which time applicants may be absent from Australia for no more than 12 months in total. Changing the length of the qualifying period of permanent residency will allow more time for the Government to assess all applicants' experience of integrating into life in Australia. Internationally, four years is at the lower end of residency requirements. Some countries, such as Denmark, require nine years continuous residence before a person can apply for citizenship. Other countries having residence requirements for citizenship through naturalisation include: the United States of America requires eligible applicants to demonstrate at least five years permanent residence; the United Kingdom requires eligible applicants to demonstrate at least five years residence; and Germany requires eligible applicants to demonstrate at least eight years residence. It should be noted that the Special Residence and Defence Service requirements currently included in the Australian Citizenship Act 2007 will remain unchanged, as will the Ministerial discretion to in effect waive the permanent residence requirements if the Minister is satisfied that the person will suffer significant hardship or disadvantage because of not meeting the requirements. The person still has to be present in Australia during the relevant period, however they may be here on a temporary visa. Further, the Australian Citizenship Legislation Amendment (Strengthening the Requirements for Australian Citizenship and Other Measures) Bill 2017 provides the Minister with a personal, noncompellable power to waive the general residence requirement where the Minister is satisfied that it is in the public interest to do so. The Australian public expects aspiring citizens to commit to Australia and Australian values, and the Government has determined that four years is an appropriate period over which to measure this commitment. All applications received on or after 20 April 2017 will be affected by the reforms announced on that date. Further information on Australian citizenship, including details on the reforms, can be found at: http://www.border.gov.au/Trav/Citi. Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention. Yours sincerely from the Minister for Immigration and Border Protection, Mr Dutton Citizenship Dear Mrs WicksI refer to correspondence from Mr Ross Vasta MP of 20 June 2017 enclosing Petition EN0200, concerning the Australian Government's reforms to strengthen the requirements for Australian citizenship. The package of reforms announced by the Prime Minister on 20 April 2017 is the Australian Government's response to the National Consultation on Citizenship, which indicated strong support for strengthening the requirements for Australian citizenship. The package of reforms includes: increasing the general residence requirement; introducing an English language test; strengthening the Australian values statement; strengthening the test for Australian citizenship; introducing a requirement for applicants to demonstrate their integration into the Australian community; and strengthening the pledge. I note the concerns raised in the Petition about the increased general residence requirement, and the introduction of an English language test. Applicants will need to be a permanent resident in Australia for a period of four years immediately prior to their application for citizenship, during which time applicants may be absent from Australia for no more than 12 months in total. Changing the length of the qualifying period of permanent residency will allow more time for the Government to assess all applicants' experience of integrating into life in Australia. Internationally, four years is at the lower end of residency requirements. Some countries, such as Denmark, require nine years continuous residence before a person can apply for citizenship. Other countries having residence requirements for citizenship through naturalisation include: the United States of America requires eligible applicants to demonstrate at least five years permanent residence; the United Kingdom requires eligible applicants to demonstrate at least five years residence; and Germany requires eligible applicants to demonstrate at least eight years residence. It should be noted that the Special Residence and Defence Service requirements currently included in the Australian Citizenship Act 2007 will remain unchanged, as will the Ministerial discretion to in effect waive the permanent residence requirements if the Minister is satisfied that the person will suffer significant hardship or disadvantage because of not meeting the requirements. The person still has to be present in Australia during the relevant period, however, they may be here on a temporary visa. Further, the Australian Citizenship Legislation Amendment (Strengthening the Requirements for Australian Citizenship and Other Measures) Bill 2017 provides the Minister with a personal, noncompellable power to waive the general residence requirement where the Minister is satisfied that it is in the public interest to do so. The reforms will also introduce a separate stand-alone English test for aspiring citizens by conferral at the competent level. A competent level of English means a generally effective command of the language despite some inaccuracies, inappropriate usage and misunderstandings; fairly complex language is used and understood, particularly in familiar situations. English language proficiency is essential for economic participation, social cohesion and integration into the Australian community. The Department of Immigration and Border Protection currently accepts English language test scores from the following test providers as evidence of English language proficiency for the purposes of migration under the Migration Act 1958: International English Language Testing System (IELTS); Occupational English Test (OET); Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL); Pearson Test of English (PTE) Academic; and Cambridge English: Advanced (CAE). however, the Department accepts either as evidence of English proficiency. Usually, people applying for higher education or professional registration take the Academic test and those who are applying for secondary education, work experience or training programmes take the General Training test. Exemptions from the English language test will apply for those applicants who: have a permanent or enduring physical or mental incapacity; are aged 60 or over, or have a hearing, speech or sight impairment; are aged under 16; or applied under the born in Papua; born to a former Australian citizen; or statelessness provisions. Limited exemptions will apply for citizens of the United Kingdom, the United States of America, Canada, New Zealand or the Republic of Ireland who hold a passport for that country when they apply for citizenship, and applicants who have undertaken specified English language studies at a recognised Australian education institution. This is consistent with the Department's current approach to determining competent English for skilled visas. All applications received on or after 20 April 2017 will be affected by the changes. Further information on Australian citizenship, including details on the reforms, can be found at: http://www.border.gov.au/TraviCiti. Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention. Yours sincerely from the Minister for Immigration and Border Protection, Mr Dutton Citizenship Dear Mrs WicksI refer to correspondence from Mr Ross Vasta MP of 20 June 2017 enclosing Petition EN0205, concerning the Australian Government's reforms to strengthen the requirements for Australian citizenship. The package of reforms announced by the Prime Minister on 20 April 2017 is the Government's response to the National Consultation on Citizenship, which indicated strong support for strengthening the requirements for Australian citizenship. The package of reforms includes: increasing the general residence requirement; introducing an English language test; strengthening the Australian values statement; strengthening the test for Australian citizenship; introducing a requirement for applicants to demonstrate their integration into the Australian community; and strengthening the pledge. All applications received on or after 20 April 2017 will be affected by the changes. I note the concerns raised in the Petition about the increased general residence requirement, and the introduction of an English language test. Applicants will need to be a permanent resident in Australia for a period of four years immediately prior to their application for citizenship, during which time applicants may be absent from Australia for no more than 12 months in total. Changing the length of the qualifying period of permanent residency will allow more time for the Government to assess all applicants' experience of integrating into life in Australia. Internationally, four years is at the lower end of residency requirements. Some countries, such as Denmark, require nine years continuous residence before a person can apply for citizenship. Other countries having residence requirements for citizenship through naturalisation include: the United States of America requires eligible applicants to demonstrate at least five years permanent residence; the United Kingdom requires eligible applicants to demonstrate at least five years residence; and Germany requires eligible applicants to demonstrate at least eight years residence. It should be noted that the Special Residence and Defence Service requirements currently included in the Australian Citizenship Act 2007 will remain unchanged, as will the Ministerial discretion to in effect waive the permanent residence requirements if the Minister is satisfied that the person will suffer significant hardship or disadvantage because of not meeting the requirements. The person still has to be present in Australia during the relevant period, however they may be here on a temporary visa. Further, the Australian Citizenship Legislation Amendment (Strengthening the Requirements for Australian Citizenship and Other Measures) Bill 2017 provides the Minister with a personal, noncompellable power to waive the general residence requirement where the Minister is satisfied that it is in the public interest to do so. The reforms will also introduce a separate stand-alone English test for aspiring citizens by conferral, which will require applicants to achieve a minimum level of 'competent'. A competent level of English means a generally effective command of the language despite some inaccuracies, inappropriate usage and misunderstandings; fairly complex language is used and understood, particularly in familiar situations. English language proficiency is essential for economic participation, social cohesion and integration into the Australian community. The Department of Immigration and Border Protection currently accepts English language test scores from the following test providers as evidence of English language proficiency for the purposes of migration under the Migration Act 1958: International English Language Testing System (IELTS); Occupational English Test (OET); Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL); Pearson Test of English (PTE) Academic; and Cambridge English: Advanced (CAE). however, the Department accepts either as evidence of English proficiency. Usually people applying for higher education or professional registration take the Academic test and those who are applying for secondary education, work experience or training programmes take the General Training test. Exemptions from the English language test will apply for those applicants who: have a permanent or enduring physical or mental incapacity; are aged 60 or over, or have a hearing, speech or sight impairment; are aged under 16; or applied under the born in Papua; born to a former Australian citizen; or statelessness provisions. Limited exemptions will apply for citizens of the United Kingdom, the United States of America, Canada, New Zealand or the Republic of Ireland who hold a passport for that country when they apply for citizenship, and applicants who have undertaken specified English language studies at a recognised Australian education institution. This is consistent with the Department's current approach to determining competent English for skilled visas. Further information on Australian citizenship, including details on the reforms, can be found at: http://www.border.gov.au/Trav/Citi. Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention. Yours sincerely from the Minister for Immigration and Border Protection, Mr Dutton Postcode Allocation Dear Mr Vasta Thank you for your letter of 20 June 2017 attaching petition EN0210 presented in the House of Representatives. The petition requests Australia Post to review the allocation of postcode 4306 and reallocate affected suburbs with more appropriate postcodes. I have brought the petition to the attention of the Chair of Australia Post. I understand that Australia Post is currently reviewing the allocation of postcode 4306 and has been consulting with residents and key stakeholders on this matter, including with local federal members of parliament. I have asked Australia Post to continue with its consultations and keep me updated on progress in this matter. A copy of my letter to the Chair is attached for your information. Thank you for bringing this matter to my attention. Yours sincerely from the Minister for Communication and the Arts, Mr Fifield Citizenship Dear Mrs Wicks Thank you for your correspondence of 16 August 2017 enclosing Petition number EN0213 in support of the Australian Government's reforms to strengthen the requirements for Australian citizenship. The package of reforms announced by the Prime Minister on 20 April 2017 is the Government's response to the National Consultation on Citizenship, which indicated strong support for strengthening the requirements for Australian citizenship. On 15 June 2017, I introduced the Australian Citizenship Legislation Amendment (Strengthening the Requirements for Australian Citizenship and other Measures) Bill 2017 (the Bill) into the Parliament. The Bill was passed by the House of Representatives on 14 August 2017 and was introduced into the Senate on 15 August 2017. The Bill is listed for debate in the Senate in September 2017. Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention. Yours sincerely from the Minister for Immigration and Border Protection, Mr Dutton Development Assistance Dear Mrs Wicks Thank you for your letter of 15 August 2017, regarding petition EN0225 recently presented to the House, on behalf of 17 signatories, concerning Australian Official Development Assistance (ODA). Australia will provide $3.9 billion in ODA in 2017-18, an increase of $84 million on 2016-17, making Australia approximately the 13th largest donor in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. The Government will not commit to a prescriptive, time bound aid target as a percentage of Gross National Income until the domestic economy is back on a sustainable footing and Australia is in a fiscally strong position to support this aspiration. I trust this information is of assistance. Yours sincerely from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mrs Bishop Assange, Mr Julian Dear Mrs Wicks Thank you for your letter of 16 August 2017, on behalf of the Standing Committee on Petitions, regarding Julian Assange (petition number EN0234). The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (DFAT) has either provided or offered consulat. assistance to Mr Assange on more than 100 occasions since 2010. This assistance remains available to Mr Assange should he choose to take it up. The offer of assistance was most recently reiterated in May 2017 via the Ecuadorian Embassy in London. The nature of the assistance available is set out in the Consular Services Charter, a copy of which I enclose for your reference.* The Australian Government is not aware of any extradition request by the United States in relation to Mr Assange. As long as Mr Assange remains in the United Kingdom, any such request remains a matter for the governments of the United States and United Kingdom. While the Swedish prosecutor has announced that it has discontinued the investigation of a rape allegation against Mr Assange, I am advised Mr Assange remains subject to outstanding legal proceedings in the United Kingdom. The Australian Government will not seek to interfere in any UK legal process, just as we would not countenance foreign interference in Australian legal processes. Should Mr Assange's outstanding legal matters be resolved, he will be free to return to Australia, just as any Australian can in such circumstances. I trust this information is of assistance. Yours sincerely from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mrs Bishop* A copy of the Consular Services Charter is available online or from the House of Representatives Table Office. Citizenship Dear Mrs Wicks Thank you for your correspondence of 16 August 2017 enclosing Petition number EN0237 concerning the Australian Government's reforms to strengthen the requirements for Australian citizenship. The package of reforms announced by the Prime Minister on 20 April 2017 is the Government's response to the National Consultation on Citizenship, which indicated strong support for strengthening the requirements for Australian citizenship. The package of reforms includes: increasing the general residence requirement; introducing an English language test; strengthening the Australian values statement; strengthening the test for Australian citizenship; introducing a requirement for applicants to demonstrate their integration into the Australian community; and strengthening the Australian citizenship pledge. All applications received on or after 20 April 2017 will be affected by the changes. I note the concerns raised in the petition about the reforms, in particular the date the reforms will come into effect and increasing the general residence requirement. The date of commencement was informed by experiences of previous Australian governments announcing reforms to programmes in the portfolio including the citizenship programme. When a new policy is announced this can result in significant increases in the number of applications, and consequential delays in the processing of these applications. On the general residence requirement, applicants will need to be a permanent resident in Australia for a period of four years immediately prior to their application for citizenship, during which time applicants may be absent from Australia for no more than 12 months in total. Changing the length of the qualifying period of permanent residency will allow more time for the Government to assess all applicants' experience of integrating into life in Australia. Internationally, four years is at the lower end of residency requirements. Some countries such as Denmark, require nine years continuous residence before a person can apply for citizenship. The comparison below is in general terms only as it does not list exemptions or discretions available to vary requirements across jurisdiction. Limitations on the amount of time spent out of the country may also apply. Other countries have residence requirements for citizenship through naturalisation: the United States of America requires eligible applicants to demonstrate at least five years permanent residence; the United Kingdom requires eligible applicants to demonstrate at least five years residence; and Germany requires eligible applicants to demonstrate at least eight years residence. Further information on Australian citizenship, including details on the reforms, is available on the Department of Immigration and Border Protection's website at: http://www.border.gov.au/Trav/Citi. Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention. Yours sincerely from the Minister for Immigration and Border Protection, Mr Dutton Islam Dear Mrs Wicks Thank you for your letter of 16 August 2017, regarding petition number EN0260 on Wahabbism in Australia. Australia is the most successful multicultural society in the world, uniting a multitude of cultures, experiences, beliefs, and traditions. We have flourished in part thanks to our cultural and religious diversity, underpinned by our common values and commitment to freedom, security, and prosperity. This diversity has increased our opportunities and, most significantly, expanded the way we see and engage with the world. People of Islamic faith have been part of the Australian story since the 1800s. Close to 40 per cent of people who identify as Muslim in Australia were born in Australia. Of those born overseas, close to 60 per cent have gained citizenship. The Australian Muslim community has made a significant positive cultural contribution to Australian society while adopting many established customs. The Australian Government recently launched its multicultural statement -Multicultural Australia: United, Strong, Successful. This statement specifically outlines the Government's commitment to freedom of religion. An electronic copy of the statement can be found at https: / www.dss.gov.au/settlement-and-multicultural-affairs/ australian-governm ents-multicultural-statement. Our position is clear: the Government supports freedom of religion as strongly as it supports freedom of thought, enterprise and association. All Australians are free to practise their religion or belief system, within Australian law, free from the threat of violence or intimidation. It is for these reasons the Australian Government will not consider a Royal Commission into Islam. Australia's foreign policy settings are aimed at making Australia stronger, safer and more prosperous by promoting and protecting our interests internationally, and contributing to global stability and economic growth. Promoting Australia as a successful, diverse multicultural country is central to these aims. The pursuit of our global, regional and bilateral interests includes engagement with Saudi Arabia as an important trade, investment and security partner in the Middle East. Saudi Arabia is a fellow G20 economy with which two-way trade was worth $2.4 billion in 2015-16. Saudi Arabian investment in Australia is estimated at $1.1 billion and there are an estimated 6000 Australians resident in Saudi Arabia with most employed in the resource (oil extraction), agriculture and services sectors. We acknowledge the efforts of Saudi Arabia in countering violent extremism in the Kingdom, and fighting extremism in the region more broadly. On 21 May 2017, during his visit to Saudi Arabia, US President Trump toured the new Global Centre for Combatting Extremist Ideology. The Centre aims to combat militant ideology and messaging and we welcome Saudi Arabia's recognition that more needs to be done in this regard. Saudi Arabia is an important partner on regional security including through our joint membership of the Global Coalition to Defeat ISIL. As a major regional power, Saudi Arabia has a key role to play and we will continue to engage at senior levels to achieve the objectives we share. Australia is concerned about any external influences that seek to propagate extreme interpretations of Islam. The Federal Government, state and territory governments and communities work together, as well as with our international partners, to build resistance to all forms of violent extremism, whether politically, religiously or racially motivated. I trust this information is of assistance. Yours sincerely from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mrs Bishop Saudi Arabia Dear Mrs Wicks Thank you for your letter of 16 August 2017 concerning petition EN0260 regarding Australia's relationship with Saudi Arabia. I will address the section of the petition relating to resources issues. Other matters raised will be addressed by the Attorney-General, Senator the Hon George Brandis. Oil is an important source of energy, supplying most of Australia's transport needs. However, Australia no longer has the domestic crude oil resources to be self-sufficient in liquid fuels. Australia relies on the global market to meet our local needs and is part of a global petroleum supply chain with access to diverse sources for oil and refined fuels. Australia sources significant quantities of both crude oil and refined petroleum products from around a dozen countries, with no country providing more than one-third of Australia's total imports of either crude oil or refined product. No crude oil or refined products were imported from Saudi Arabia in 201617. Although Australia has limited domestic supplies of oil currently, there remains potential for discovery of additional oil resources. Facilitating discovery of the next major oil province is a priority for me and my portfolio agencies. Australian governments do not undertake commercial petroleum exploration or development directly; rather, governments provide a regulatory framework for exploration, development, safety, environmental assessment and revenue collection. The Australian Government's annual Offshore Petroleum Exploration Acreage Release (acreage release) is a key part of the Australian Government's strategy to promote petroleum exploration in Australia's offshore waters. The acreage release provides explorers with new offshore areas to explore via a bidding process. Each year my department works with Geoscience Australia to offer a variety of investment opportunities supported by pre-competitive geological and geophysical data and analysis. The 2017 acreage release includes areas for bidding in the Bass, Otway and Gippsland Basins that are all proven oil-producing basins. More information about the acreage release and promoting petroleum exploration offshore Australia can be found at www.petroleum-acreage.gov.au. Thank you again for writing on this matter. I trust my comments are of assistance. Yours sincerely from the Minister for Agriculture and Water Resources, Mr Joyce Climate Change Dear Mrs Wicks Thank you for your letter of 16 August 2017 regarding Petition number EN0264 requesting that Australia withdraw from the Paris Agreement on climate change. Australia's ratification of the Paris Agreement on 10 November 2016 enjoyed bipartisan support. The Joint Standing Committee on Treaties carefully considered a National Interest Analysis, as well as public hearings and submissions before recommending that Australia ratify the Agreement. Under the Paris Agreement, Australia has an ambitious, yet responsible target to reduce emissions by 26 to 28 per cent below 2005 levels by 2030. This target is comparable with other advanced economies. The Paris Agreement has been signed by over 190 Parties. The Agreement has been ratified by 160 of these Parties, including the European Union, Indonesia, China, India and Japan, and came into force a year after its adoption. Australia has a good track record of reducing emissions without harming the economy. For example, under the Kyoto Protocol, Australia beat our first target and remains on track to beat our 2020 target by 224 million tonnes, while the Australian economy enters its 26th year of continuous growth. I trust that this information is of some assistance. Yours sincerely from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mrs Bishop Veterans Dear Mrs Wicks Thank you for your letter of 16 August 2017 about petition number EN0269, regarding consideration of Gold Cards being provided to surviving members of Australian civilian medical teams who volunteered during the Vietnam War. The members of the civilian surgical-medical teams who worked in Vietnam between 1964 and 1972 were part of the Australian Government's contribution to the South-East Asia Treaty Organisation (SEATO) aid program, and were civilian employees of the former Department of External Affairs. I have previously raised this matter with the Minister for Foreign Affairs, the Hon Julie Bishop MP. Ms Bishop has advised me that as former employees of the then Department of External Affairs, these men and women have access to compensation and medical treatment under the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988 (SRCA), which is administered by Comcare. I am advised that prior to deploying to South Vietnam, team members signed an acceptance of general public service terms and conditions of employment, including coverage under the Commonwealth employees compensation legislation that applied at the time, which is now the SRCA. Whilst in South Vietnam, the civilian employees came under the jurisdiction of the Australian Ambassador in Saigon and on a day to day basis were administered by the Counsellor (Aid) at the Embassy. A core principle of military compensation legislation is that it provides support and compensation that acknowledges the special and unique nature of, and dangers associated with, military service. Gold Card eligibility generally rests on a person having the necessary 'qualifying service', or a high-level of disability related to military service. Qualifying service during the Vietnam War requires that a member of the Australian Defence Force (ADF) has been "... a member of a unit of the Defence Force that was allotted for duty, or as a person that was allotted for duty, in that area." The main objectives of the noted above, the teams were civilians, employed by the Department of External Affairs, and at no time were they allotted for duty, under ADF command or contributed to ADF operations. As noted by the committee conducting the Review of Military Compensation Arrangements (2011), 'It is an everyday occurrence for ADF members, Australian Government public servants and contractors to work in close proximity to each other either in Australia or in overseas missions and posts while being covered by different compensation Acts.' Any member of the SEATO aid program who has suffered an injury or illness as a result of their employment in South Vietnam can apply to Comcare for support under the SRCA. This support extends to any condition that developed after they left South Vietnam that can be attributed to their employment. Under the SRCA, incapacity payments are payable until retirement age and other benefits are payable for the lifetime of their condition. Details of the benefits that are available to members of the SEATO aid program can be found on the Comcare website at www.comcare.gov.au. Assistance with lodging a claim can also be obtained by contacting Mr Alan Burrows from the Rehabilitation and Staff Support Team in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. Mr Burrows can be contacted on (02) 6178 5575 or by email at rehab@dfat.gov.au. I thank you for raising this matter with me, however, there is no basis for the provision of the Gold Card to this group under military compensation legislation. As they were civilians employed by the then Department of External Affairs and were not under ADF command and control, I would suggest that issues relating to treatment and compensation for this group are best placed with Ms Bishop and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. Yours sincerely from the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Mr Tehan Mobile Black Spot Program Dear Mr Vasta Thank you for your letter of 15 June 2017, to Senator the Hon Mitch Fifield, Minister for Communications and the Arts, regarding a Petition before the Standing Committee on Petitions. This petition seeks funding under the next round of the Mobile Black Spot Program for the Heybridge, Preservation Bay and Sulphur Creek communities in Tasmania. As the matters raised fall with in my portfolio responsibilities, your letter has been forwarded to me for reply. While mobile carriers claim to provide coverage to 99 per cent of Australia's population, there are still many parts of Australia where there is no coverage, particularly in regional and remote locations. Expanding mobile coverage has clear economic and social benefits for people living, working and travelling in regional and remote areas of Australia. The Australian Government has committed $220 million through the Mobile Black Spot Program (the Program) to invest in telecommunications infrastructure to address mobile black spots along major regional transport routes and in small communities. The Government's commitment to the Program includes $60 million to target specific priority locations. A full list of these priority locations is available on the Department of Communications and the Arts website at www.communications.gov.au/mobile coverage. I am pleased to advise that Sulphur Creek has been announced as a priority location under this round of the Program. Given the close proximity of Heybridge and Preservation Bay to Sulphur Creek, these locations may benefit from a future base station funded to provide services to Sulphur Creek. However, due to the topography of the area any improvements in coverage may be a mix of handheld and external antenna coverage. Consultations have now commenced with the mobile carriers and the States on the implementation of the priority locations round of the program. There will be an approach to market in 2017 to deliver on these commitments, subject to suitable applications being submitted by the mobile carriers. Thank you again for taking the time to write to Minister Fifield on this matter. Yours sincerely from the Minister for Regional Development, Ms Nash Development Assistance Dear Mrs Wicks Thank you for your letter of 15 August 2017, regarding petition PN0065 recently presented to the House on behalf of 27 signatories, concerning Australian Official Development Assistance (ODA). Australia will provide $3.9 billion in ODA in 2017-18, an increase of $84 million on 2016-17, making Australia approximately the 13th largest donor in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. The Government will not commit to a prescriptive, time bound aid target as a percentage of Gross National Income until the domestic economy is back on a sustainable footing and Australia is in a fiscally strong position to support this aspiration. I trust this information is of assistance. Yours sincerely from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mrs Bishop Senators and Members: Code of Conduct Dear Mrs Wicks Thank you for your letters dated 4 September 2017 to the Prime Minister regarding petitions to House of Representatives. The petitions relate to parliamentarians being tested for illegal drugs and alcohol, and a code of conduct for all Senators and Members. The Prime Minister has asked me to reply on his behalf. The issues raised in the petitions relate to the conduct of parliamentarians and are matters for the Parliament to determine. Yours sincerely
title: Petitions

speaker: From The Assistant Minister To The Prime Minister, Mr Mcgrath
theText: Statements Committee, with the receipt of a record number of paper petitions for this parliament. All 40 petitions on this report are paper petitions, 31 of which are part of a nationally-coordinated electorate-based campaign. Petitioning the parliament is an age-old democratic tradition, and, while paper petitioning is the original and well-used format, I can assure you, Mr Speaker, that e-petitions remain a popular format for submitting petitions. At last count we were up to 397 e-petitions and 160 paper petitions for this parliament. As a comparison, recent parliaments have only received between 100 and 200 and we are only a year into the 45th Parliament. E-petitioning provides electronic options, and members of the public continue to embrace this new style of petitioning. As part of the committee's inquiry into e-petitions last week, the committee took evidence from the ACT Legislative Assembly about their e-petition system. It was interesting to note that the ACT Legislative Assembly informed the committee that it has also noted a marked increase in petitions, both electronic and paper. It's heartening to hear positive feedback about how people are finding it easier to engage with parliament and have their concerns reach their elected representatives via petitions. This week, the Petitions Committee looks forward to hearing from the Parliament of Tasmania on their e-petitioning system, as well as from representatives from the Federation of Ethnic Communities Councils of Australia about how our system can meet the needs of all Australians. I'll continue to provide updates to the House on the work of the Petitions Committee and the inquiry into e-petitions. Coal-Fired Power Funding Prohibition Bill 2017 [No. 2] First Reading Bill and explanatory memorandum presented by Mr Bandt. Bill read a first time. Second Reading That this bill be now read a second time. Coal is on its way out. It's an industry in decline and almost every other leader in the world seems to get that except for our Prime Minister and for Donald Trump. The world is rapidly moving away from dirty old coal, which is a legacy technology, and making the transition towards clean, green renewable energy. In 2017, coal makes no sense. It doesn't stack up environmentally or economically and it is literally killing people. Not only is the pollution from coal-fired power stations making global warming worse, but chemicals like mercury and sulphur dioxide are also being spewed into our atmosphere from burning coal. In Australia, we emit mercury at double the global average, and inhaling it and other toxic chemicals carries serious health risks.

title: Bills

speaker: Mr Bandt (Melbourne) (10:03
theText: I move:Coal doesn't even work when you need it to. During the heatwaves in New South Wales this year, Liddell Power Station was unable to perform as two of its generator units were unable to switch on due to unforeseen boiler tube leaks. There's a reason that no-one in the private sector is building new coal-fired power stations. It doesn't stack up economically. No-one is interested in investing billions of dollars into a giant coal-fired power station that no-one is going to want to switch on in a few years. No-one is interested in sinking capital investment into an ageing technology when the cost of renewables is plummeting and getting cheaper by the day. Investing in coal is about as sensible as investing in a company that builds fax machines and typewriters. The cost of renewables is plummeting and we live in one of the sunniest, windiest places in the world. If the government had any vision, they'd be positioning Australia to take advantage of the clean energy revolution. We would be leading the world in renewable energy technology, we'd have some of the lowest prices in the world and we'd be reducing pollution across the country. Instead, we're being left behind. Whilst the minister waxes lyrical about the falling cost of renewables, he's failing to do what other countries are doing, which is putting in place legislated targets to increase their uptake. China is getting on with it and introducing an emissions trading scheme. While the Treasurer and the Deputy Prime Minister throw around chunks of coal in parliament, Germany has been getting up to 85 per cent of its electricity from renewable sources on sunny, windy days this year. To ensure that we transition to a nation that is powered by renewables, we need to do two things at once. One is rapidly introduce clean, cheap, reliable renewable energy into the system, and the second is to conduct an orderly retirement of coal-fired power stationsrenewables in, coal out, and a legislated program to do it. But that hasn't stopped this government from peddling their dangerous obsession with coal, and so now the parliament has to stop them. The conservatives in this place only live and die by the market when it suits them. Right now, around the world, people are forcing out coal and the falling cost of renewables and storage is only going to make them more competitive. But here we've had members of the government recently talking about frantically pulling on one of the only levers that are left available to them-using public money that should be going to schools and hospitals to instead fund coal. This is a truly desperate and despicable step by a Prime Minister that's doing anything he can to hang onto power. The government has been prosecuting the case hard to keep the decrepit old clunker Liddell Power Station open, for example. That joint-having been out to Bayswater and Liddell and visited the sites as part of visiting coal-fired power station communities around Australia this year, can I say that place is being held together by spit and sticky tape. Liddell is falling apart, and its current owners, AGL, don't want to spend the money on keeping it open. So the government is still, despite its recent announcement last week, bringing public pressure to bear to say, 'Keep it open,' and is leaving the door open to tipping in public money to make sure that the Liddell coal-fired power station stays open. It should be illegal and unlawful to use public money in this way-public money that could be going to schools and hospitals and should be going there; public money that should be spent on science and research; public money that should be spent on reducing inequality in this country and ensuring that everyone has access to a high-quality education; public money that should be spent securing our renewable energy future; and public money that should be used in the public interest. If the government is wanting to use public money to burn our planet and make climate change worse, that should be illegal. We have to stop them. The bill So the Greens bill that I introduce today, the Coal-Fired Power Funding Prohibition Bill 2017, prohibits:  the Commonwealth providing financial support to refurbish or build a coal-fired power station; and  the Commonwealth purchasing, or assisting with the purchase or transfer or ownership of, a coal-fired power station However, this bill does ensure that the government can use public money to transition affected workers into new industry and use public money to manage the closure of a coalfired power station. Let's be very clear about this. Coal kills, whether it's through the toxic pollutants it spews into the atmosphere that affect the air we breathe, or the global warming that it accelerates that will destroy our way of life. We need to stop burning coal. And already, industry and investment are moving away from coal. No major financial institution in Australia wants to finance the Adani coal megamine and no-one in the private sector is interested in building new coal-fired power stations. But this government and the Trumps on the backbench that control it are resisting and opposing what the markets that they claim to worship are telling them, what the science is telling them, what the private sector is telling them, what public opinion is telling them and, most importantly, what the world is telling them. In their blind, dangerous resistance they are turning to the only option they have left: a culture war, using coal as a proxy for their failing grip on public opinion. They're using their leverage over Malcolm Turnbull to condemn our future generations, and the Greens are willing to stand in the way. Why? Because you can't count on the Labor opposition to do it. Labor and Liberals are wedded to each other and wedded to coal. The Labor Party tries to talk the talk on renewables and a clean energy target, but when the Greens introduce a motion into this place and into the Senate to rule out any attempts to extend the life of Liddell and to develop a plan for the orderly transition away from coal, where does Labor vote? Labor votes with the government, because when push comes to shove the Labor opposition is still beholden to the fossil fuel companies. Labor is still in the pocket of coal. But, worse still, the revolving door between big interests isn't just for the coalition, but the Labor Party as well. According to an article published in The Conversation on 22 June last year, former ministers Martin Ferguson and Craig Emerson either took up management jobs with mining and energy companies and associations or worked as consultants for them. Earlier this year, The Australian revealed that Cameron Milner, who has worked for the Premier of Queensland and in the Leader of the Opposition's office, was volunteering with the ALP while keeping his day job as a director and registered lobbyist at Next Level Strategic Services (NLSS), which counts amongst its clients Indian miner Adani. Plan But the Greens have a plan. We've got a plan to extend the Renewable Energy Target, which-despite what others like the member for Warringah, former Prime Minister Abbott is saying-is working, a plan to legislate a national storage target to run Australia on 100 per cent renewable energy, a plan to transition workers from coal communities into the jobs of the future and a plan to re-regulate electricity prices to bring down costs and provide muchneeded relief for households around this country. We've laid out this plan and we're confident that, if it was implemented, we could stabilise the grid, restore investment confidence and end the investment strike on renewables, bring down pollution, bring down prices and even meet our paltry Paris obligations. It is ideology and weakness, from the old parties, that is standing in the way of the energy revolution. Instead, what we are served up from this government is fear-mongering that falsely blames blackouts on renewables. It is juvenile name-calling in the chamber and it's a government that, instead of taking real action to bring down prices, forces energy retailers to write letters to customers telling them just exactly how much they're being ripped off. Well, enough is enough. I urge the opposition Labor Party and my colleagues right across the spectrum in this parliament to find the courage to support this bill so that we can take one important step forward, when the government insists on going backwards. Our precious public money should not be used to prop up clunky and dirty coal-fired power stations. There are better uses for it. If the government doesn't understand that, and if members of the government still want to talk about using public money to build new coal-fired power stations or extend their life, then this parliament needs to make sure we do not waste our money on building coal-fired power stations ever again. I commend this bill to the House. Mr Wilkie: I second the motion and reserve my right to speak. allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting.
